P EDRO SÁNCHEZ对卷土重来并不陌生：2016 年他作为社会党领袖被罢免，他在全国巡回演出以争取支持并在次年重新获得控制权。而且他不是菜鸟赌徒； 2018 年，他作为反对党领袖发起了一项不信任动议，出人意料地任命他为总理。他也不是一个糟糕的政治争吵者：在 2019 年的选举之后，他与自那以后一直团结在一起的激进左派 Podemos 一起组建了一个尴尬的少数派政府。

随着桑切斯先生进行另一场赌博，所有这些品质现在都得到了展示。 5 月 29 日，他宣布在 7 月 23 日提前举行选举，此前一天，他的政党在地区和市政选举中惨败。保守的反对党人民党 ( PP ) 不仅赢得了瓦伦西亚地区（它失去的前堡垒）和阿拉贡地区（一个更难的目标）。它甚至在西南部的埃斯特雷马杜拉地区获胜，自从 1978 年弗朗西斯科佛朗哥死后西班牙恢复民主以来，社会党几乎一直控制着该地区。其他地区和标志性城市也从左向右摆动。

PP的领导人 Alberto Núñez Feijóo 在语气和政策上采取了温和的路线，并从 Ciudadanos 的最终消亡中获益，Ciudadanos 是一个自由的中右翼政党，在 2019 年做出决定后陷入死亡螺旋，不要与桑切斯先生一起进入政府。 PP似乎已经囊括了所有的选民，解释了它的巨大收益。

现在，两大政党必须注意自己的侧翼。保守派是在上一个选举周期中出现的极右翼 Vox。人民党需要其支持才能在其刚刚赢得的大部分地区进行治理。 Vox 不仅仅满足于支持PP少数民族政府，还想加入地区政府（就像它已经在卡斯蒂利亚和莱昂所做的那样）。 Feijóo 先生向 Sánchez 先生提供了一项协议，根据该协议，无论哪个政党获胜，每个地区都应被允许执政，即使没有多数席位，以将极端主义政党拒之门外。但桑切斯先生似乎更愿意强迫 PP 与 Vox 一起执政，因此将 7 月的选举描绘成对强硬右翼崛起的全民公投。

但桑切斯先生也有他自己的问题。他的联盟伙伴 Podemos 遭到猛烈抨击。现在社会党的左翼政党必须迅速重组。西班牙劳工部长兼副首相约兰达·迪亚斯 (Yolanda Díaz) 过去曾与 Podemos 结盟，但现在领导着一个名为 Sumar 的新组织。她推行民粹主义（而且通常很受欢迎）经济政策，而 Podemos 则将其旗帜钉在身份政治问题上；一年中的大部分时间里，对强奸法的拙劣改革一直困扰着该党。 Sumar和Podemos尚未决定是否重组。西班牙的选举制度惩罚小党派；如果他们分开运行，双方都会受到影响。

在周末的选举之后，右翼势头强劲。桑切斯先生几乎没有时间去发现另一个才能：将军在已经忙于战斗的同时改写他的战略。他只给自己八周的时间来做这件事。 ■

; Mon, 29 May 2023 15:45:00 GMT /内容/ganvmtdatuol0nfkanr75pck1vli5u4t https://www.economist.com/podcasts/2023/05/29/why-donald-trump-is-likely-to-be-the-republican-nominee-for-president-how-to-fix-britains-国家卫生服务和公司的创造力休假日 Bad Bunny, a superstar rapper, is good business

本月早些时候的一天， Spotify 播放量最高的四首歌曲是“Ella Baila Sola”，这是一首带有突出长号的欢快曲调； “Where She Goes”，混合了R&B和说唱； “un x100to”，中速，大量使用原声吉他和手风琴，以及“La Bebe”，一种缓慢的，主要是电子雷鬼乐，一种来自波多黎各的风格，节奏改编自牙买加舞厅。从表面上看，这些歌曲几乎没有共同之处。但是，当天播放量超过 2000 万次的世界前四名歌曲确实有一个共同特点：它们都是用西班牙语演唱的。

同样，在 5 月 18 日当周流媒体播放量最高的 20 首歌曲中，有九首是西班牙语。 11 月，Spotify 连续第三年将来自波多黎各的说唱歌手 Bad Bunny（如图）加冕为流媒体播放量最高的艺人。这是流媒体服务历史上第一次有人长期统治其排行榜。在 YouTube 上，来自墨西哥的歌手 Peso Pluma 甚至超越了 Bad Bunny，其前 20 首歌曲中的三首都有表演。根据美国唱片业协会的数据，去年在美国，拉丁音乐创造了 10 亿美元的唱片收入，年增长率为 24%。这是美国音乐总收入的 7%，创历史新高。

西班牙音乐正在流行。这种成功不仅跨越了音乐流派，也跨越了不同的媒体。哥伦比亚关于器官贩卖的惊悚片“The Marked Heart”的两季在 Netflix 的非英语节目中名列前十。西班牙电视连续剧“Money Heist”是 Netflix 在非英语排行榜上按观看时间计算的有史以来观看次数最多的电视剧。根据伦敦经济学院访问学者威尔佩奇和音乐家克里斯达拉里瓦的新论文，“金钱抢劫”是阿根廷、巴西、智利、法国、意大利和葡萄牙收视率最高的节目。它在北非、中东和土耳其也很受欢迎。三部西班牙语电影跻身其非英语排行榜前十名（见表格）。

英语文化不会很快失去其全球影响力。但西班牙语音乐、电影和电视的势不可挡的崛起反映了几种相互关联的趋势。首先，它显示了 Spotify 和 YouTube 等流媒体服务的重要性日益增加。它暗示了拉丁美洲人，尤其是年轻人，是如何渴望在文化上花钱的——而且他们与该地区其他人的共同点比他们想象的要多。它还展示了拉丁美洲移民如何移居国外并将他们的文化带走。通过这样做，他们正在塑造全世界的品味。

西班牙媒体在世界舞台上并不陌生。从 1960 年代开始，加夫列尔·加西亚·马尔克斯和马里奥·巴尔加斯·略萨的小说吸引了读者和评委。从西班牙的路易斯·布努埃尔 (Luis Buñuel) 和佩德罗·阿莫多瓦 (Pedro Almodóvar) 到墨西哥的“三个朋友”（吉列尔莫·德尔·托罗 (Guillermo del Toro)、亚历杭德罗·伊纳里图 (Alejandro Iñárritu) 和阿方索·卡隆)，电影一直是一种力量。 Telenovelas是一种长期的出口产品，其普遍的戏剧与埃及人和厄瓜多尔人相关。

有几件事正在推动新的繁荣。首先是拉丁美洲精通互联网的特性。该地区约有 10 亿人拥有手机。他们也可能将更多时间花在社交媒体上：据估计，阿根廷人、巴西人、哥伦比亚人和墨西哥人平均每天花三个半小时在社交媒体上，比全球平均水平多一小时。

这种繁荣的第二个原因是这些音乐家跨越国界。音乐的这种合作性质意味着大牌的吸引力远不止在他们的祖国。更重要的是，粉丝是敬业的。根据《经济学人》对 Spotify 五年数据的分析，截至 2021 年，与世界其他地区的听众相比，西班牙语音乐听众更有可能主要收听同一位艺术家的作品。

这可能会让该地区的许多人感到惊讶。世界上的西班牙裔人并不总是表现得好像他们共享一种文化。流派和国家之间的界限经常成为障碍：波多黎各莎莎音乐家举行罢工，抗议 1970 年代多米尼加音乐家将梅伦格舞带到他们的岛屿。

如今，热门歌曲通常会在主要景点旁边客串明星。以波多黎各歌手路易斯·丰西 (Luis Fonsi) 于 2017 年创作的歌曲“Despacito”为例，与同样来自波多黎各的说唱歌手洋基老爹 (Daddy Yankee) 合作。它在 36 个国家/地区连续 11 周位居榜首，部分原因是加拿大流行巨星贾斯汀比伯 (Justin Bieber) 的混音版。这首歌在美国的销量和流量超过了 1300 万。直到 2020 年儿童视频“Baby Shark”超越它，这首原创歌曲才成为有史以来观看次数最多的 YouTube 视频。迄今为止，它已经吸引了超过 80 亿次观看。同样，西班牙巨星 Rosalía 不仅与 Bad Bunny 一起唱歌，还与来自波多黎各的未婚夫 Rauw Alejandro 一起唱歌。她在 Spotify 上的播放量已超过 80 亿次，场馆销售一空。 5 月，她在墨西哥城吸引了 160,000 名粉丝。

同样，Becky G（来自加利福尼亚）与 Peso Pluma 和 Feid（哥伦比亚）与 Young Miko（波多黎各）一起演唱。阿根廷制作人 Bizarrap 将合作作为他的品牌，与来自拉丁美洲各地的其他人一起制作了热门歌曲。他与夏奇拉（哥伦比亚）的歌曲向她的前夫西班牙前足球运动员杰拉德·皮克发泄，迅速打破了流媒体记录，成为 Spotify 上 24 小时内播放量最大的拉丁音乐曲目，也是在 Spotify 上观看次数最快达到 1 亿次的拉丁曲目YouTube，只用了两天多的时间。

但最大的因素是美国的作用。尽管西班牙音乐和电视在其他地方很受欢迎，但拉丁美洲的北部邻国至关重要。 2021 年，美国西班牙裔人口达到 6250 万，占总人口的 19%。自 2010 年以来，西班牙裔占该国人口增长的 52%。这意味着西班牙语媒体拥有庞大的受众群体。拉美移民的孩子似乎也仍然拥有他们父母家的身份。尽管美国被称为移民语言的“坟场”，但 72% 的西班牙裔美国人以西班牙语为主或双语。即使在第三代，也有大约四分之一的人仍然会说双语。

因此，西班牙语可能会得到提升。该语言有大约 5 亿人以该语言为母语，比普通话和印地语以外的任何其他语言都多。 Bad Bunny 等人的冷静可能会刺激新的学习者。在 Netflix 大热的“Squid Game”之后，语言学习应用 Duolingo 的韩语注册人数突然激增。客户对西班牙语的兴趣更广泛、更持久：一位高管辛迪·布兰科 (Cindy Blanco) 表示，在英语之后，它吸引了迄今为止该应用程序上最活跃的用户。同样，付费语言应用 Babbel 在 2022 年第一季度至 2023 年第一季度期间发现西班牙语学习者增长了 42%。其中大部分在美国。

这正在影响西班牙语世界的其他地区。马德里西班牙语办公室主任拉米罗·维拉帕迪尔纳 (Ramiro Villapadierna) 指出，西班牙儿童对拉丁美洲口音和表达方式的影响几乎没有西班牙人的势利眼。政府甚至试图通过促进马德里的电影和音乐制作来驾驭拉丁浪潮。相比之下，葡萄牙媒体在该国观看 YouTube 的年轻人中对该国的巴西主义产生了轻微的道德恐慌。最近一份报纸的标题警告说：“孩子们 [are] 沉迷于来自巴西的葡萄牙语”。

西班牙文化影响力日益增强的另一个结果更加微妙。雷鬼的标志性三拍“tresillo”节奏现在可以在 Ed Sheeran、Dua Lipa 和 Drake 等歌手的英语音乐中听到。即使听众不知道，他们听到的是拉丁节拍。 ■

; Mon, 29 May 2023 10:23:53 GMT /内容/ul5jm3347qa5kbasnaqne19f2a53j9dc https://www.economist.com/podcasts/2023/05/29/erdogans-presidential-win-in-turkey-shows-just-how-much-power-he-already-had Recep Tayyip Erdogan is re-elected as Turkey’s president

与之前的许多选举一样，关于雷杰普·塔伊普·埃尔多安 (Recep Tayyip Erdogan) 在政治上垮台的谣言被证明是被大大夸大了。 5月28日，土耳其总统选举第二轮投票几乎全部开启，土耳其领导人获得52.1%的选票，足以宣告胜利。他的挑战者 Kemal Kilicdaroglu 的得票率为 47.9%。埃尔多安先生已经统治土耳其 20 年，先是担任总理，然后担任总统，现在他将能够再统治五年，甚至更多。

埃尔多安先生站在伊斯坦布尔乌斯屈达尔区 Camlica 清真寺附近停放的竞选巴士车顶向支持者发表讲话，发出几声团结一致的声音，然后恢复正常。 “今天唯一的赢家是土耳其，”他宣称。几分钟后，他称反对派为 LGBT同情者。 “对我们来说，家庭是神圣的，”他说。他仍处于竞选模式，着眼于定于明年 3 月举行的土耳其地方选举。 “没有停止，”他说。

在大约 1,000 公里外的塞克罗巴村，一名中年妇女站在自家房屋的废墟前，挥舞着镶嵌在金属长条上的土耳其国旗。汽车呼啸而过，赞许地按着喇叭。四个月前，塞克罗巴村发生强烈地震，摧毁了数百座房屋，造成近 200 人死亡。救援队一直没有出现。与南部许多地方一样，同样的地震夺去了 50,000 多人的生命，这场灾难并未削弱对埃尔多安先生的支持。在 2018 年的选举中，土耳其总统在塞克罗巴所属选区特克格鲁赢得了 78% 的选票。五年后，他以 82% 的得票率脱颖而出。当地人说，他们只信任一个人来投票，并负责地震恢复工作。 “我们爱他，”挥舞着土耳其国旗的女人说。 “为了祈祷的呼唤，为了我们的家园，为了我们的头巾。”

在推翻埃尔多安先生的一代人中，土耳其的反对派发挥了最好的作用。六个反对党已经确定了一项全面的改革方案和一名总统候选人。经济已经并将继续受到去年高达 86% 的通货膨胀的破坏，这在很大程度上是一种奇怪的货币政策的结果，该政策将低利率视为降低消费价格的方式。 2 月的地震覆盖了保加利亚那么大的废墟，暴露了劣质建筑方法、腐败和准备不足。

但这些都不足以击败埃尔多安先生。使用帮助他在一次又一次选举中获胜的相同剧本，土耳其的强人通过煽动土耳其文化战争的火焰并将反对派描述为对土耳其文化和国家安全的威胁，再次获胜。他利用 Kilicdaroglu 先生从该国主要的库尔德政党获得的支持，指责他的对手与武装分离主义组织库尔德工人党( PKK ) 勾结。投票前几天，埃尔多安先生漫不经心地承认，他在一次群众集会上播放的一段声称显示库尔德工人党战士演唱基利达罗格鲁竞选歌曲的视频实际上是假的。

媒体偏见也有帮助。私人新闻频道主要由受惠于埃尔多安先生的商人经营，而官方媒体已成为他政府的一个分支，为总统提供无限的播出时间，拒绝质疑他在镜头前的毫无根据的说法，在他不在的时候反刍它们。

Kilicdaroglu 先生主要出现在社交媒体上，以及少数与反对派关系密切的渠道。他最近试图通过承诺将驻扎在土耳其的数百万难民遣送回国并排除与库尔德工人党的和平谈判来赢得强硬右翼的支持，但没有按计划进行。民族主义候选人思南·奥根在第一轮中以 5.2% 的得票率获胜，在第二轮中支持埃尔多安先生。他的许多选民似乎也这样做。埃尔多安先生以大约 230 万票的优势获胜，仅略低于他在第一轮投票中领先的 250 万票。

已经失去了修复土耳其民主和经济的机会。反对派曾承诺推翻埃尔多安先生创建的强大的行政总统职位，这是一人统治的蓝图；至少释放一些土耳其的政治犯；并将权力交还给名义上独立的国家机构，首先是中央银行，然后是议会。埃尔多安先生现在可以随心所欲地进行统治，利用他积累的不受约束的权力来使法院、中央银行和他自己的政党保持一致。

很快，土耳其人将不得不开始关注汇率，而不是民意调查数字和选举结果。为了帮助埃尔多安赢得选举，土耳其央行每周都在出售数十亿美元的外汇储备，以防止土耳其货币里拉出现挤兑，并防止通胀失控。结果是一种被高估的货币，尽管它在过去五年中兑美元贬值了 80%。

但问题越来越多。央行的净外汇储备自 2002 年以来首次出现负值。包括与当地银行和外国的掉期交易在内，净储备估计超过 700 亿美元处于亏损状态。压力的迹象已经很明显了。自第一轮总统选举以来，里拉已下跌 2%，跌至 1 美元兑 20 里拉的历史新低。除非埃尔多安先生改变方向并决定提高利率，否则一旦中央银行用尽捍卫货币的方法，货币就会暴跌。

埃尔多安先生暗示这将是他的最后一个任期。这不一定是真的。根据埃尔多安先生在 2017 年推动通过的宪法修正案，如果议会在任期结束前提前举行选举，则第二任期的总统可以连任第三届。由于埃尔多安先生的联盟在议会中拥有 600 个席位中的 323 个，这很容易实现。假设他的健康状况良好，现年 69 岁的埃尔多安先生可能会继续掌权到 2030 年代。 ■

; Sun, 28 May 2023 20:08:23 GMT /内容/1uj0fkr97f2cpmok50hm5fidhv48b9kd https://www.economist.com/europe/2023/05/28/recep-tayyip-erdogan-is-re-elected-as-turkeys-president A new wave of mass migration has begun

去年有120万人移居英国——几乎可以肯定是有史以来最多的。澳大利亚的净移民（即移民减去移民）目前是 covid-19 大流行之前的两倍。西班牙的同等数字最近创下历史新高。预计今年将有近 140 万净人口移居美国，比大流行前多三分之一。 2022 年，加拿大的净移民人数是之前记录的两倍多。在德国，这一数字甚至高于 2015 年“移民危机”期间。整个富裕世界正处于前所未有的移民热潮之中。它的外国出生人口增长速度比历史上任何时候都快（见图 1）。

这对全球经济意味着什么？不久前，许多富裕国家似乎果断地反对大规模移民。 2016 年，英国人投票支持英国脱欧，然后美国人投票支持唐纳德特朗普——这两个政治项目都带有强烈的反移民倾向。在随后的全球民粹主义浪潮中，从澳大利亚到匈牙利的政界人士承诺要打击移民。然后 covid 关闭了边界。随着人们决定返回家园，移民活动停滞不前，甚至出现倒退。 2019 年至 2021 年间，科威特和新加坡这两个通常接收大量移民的国家的人口下降了 4%。 2021 年，澳大利亚移民人数自 1940 年代以来首次超过移民人数。

在一些地方，移民激增带来了一种常态感。 新加坡的外国劳动力最近恢复到大流行前的水平。在其他地方，这感觉像是一个巨大的变化。以加拿大人口第二少的省份纽芬兰和拉布拉多为例。长期以来，爱尔兰天主教徒后裔的家园——口音相匹配——该省的净移民人数是大流行前正常水平的 20 多倍。首都圣约翰曾经相当同质化，但每次访问时都感觉更像多伦多。 Heart's Delight 是一个小乡村，现在有一家乌克兰面包店 Borsch。省政府正在班加罗尔设立一个办公室，帮助招聘护士。

纽芬兰的新移民是富裕世界其他地方的缩影。数百名乌克兰人已抵达该岛——在俄罗斯入侵后离开该国的数百万人中，这只是一小部分。印度人和尼日利亚人似乎也在大量迁徙。许多人会说英语。许多人已经在富裕国家有亲戚关系，尤其是英国和加拿大。

移民激增的部分原因是人们正在弥补失去的时间。许多移民在 2020 年或 2021 年获得了签证，但只是在 covid 限制放松后才开始旅行。然而，富裕国家的外国出生人口（远远超过 1 亿）现在高于危机前的趋势，这表明正在发生其他事情。

大流行后经济的性质是一个很大的解释。发达国家的失业率为 4.8%，几十年来从未如此低过。老板急需员工，职位空缺接近历史最高水平。因此，来自国外的人有充分的理由去旅行。货币走势可能是另一个因素。 1 英镑可兑换 100 多印度卢比，而 2019 年为 90 卢比。自 2021 年初以来，新兴市场货币兑美元平均贬值约 4%。这使移民能够比以前寄更多的钱回家。

许多政府也在努力吸引更多人。加拿大的明确目标是在 2023-25 年迎来 150 万新居民。德国和印度最近签署了一项协议，允许更多的印度人在德国工作和学习。澳大利亚正在将一些学生毕业后可以工作的时间从两年增加到四年。英国欢迎希望逃离中国压迫的香港人——已经有超过 100,000 人抵达英国。许多国家已经让乌克兰人很容易进入。即使是那些迄今对移民怀有敌意的国家，包括日本和韩国，在寻求抵消人口老龄化的影响时，也更加青睐外来者。

从长远来看，欢迎大量移民的经济体往往会受益。看看美国就知道了。外国人带来了新的想法。根据麻省理工学院的皮埃尔·阿祖莱 (Pierre Azoulay) 及其同事最近发表的一篇论文，在美国，移民创办公司的可能性比本土出生的人高 80%。研究表明，移民还有助于在本国与接收国之间建立贸易和投资联系。一大批年轻工人也有助于产生更多的税收。

你的人就是我的人

一些经济学家还希望移民潮能带来更直接的好处。 “大量移民对美联储有帮助，因为它试图为劳动力市场降温并减缓通胀，”资产管理公司阿波罗全球管理公司的 Torsten Slok 表示，他表达了一个共同的观点。这样的论点可能有点过于乐观了。拥有更多的人确实会增加劳动力供应，而在其他条件相同的情况下，这会降低工资增长。但是效果很小。几乎没有迹象表明接收最多移民的国家的劳动力市场最松散。例如，在加拿大，薪酬仍同比增长约 5%（见图 2）。

移民还增加了对商品和服务的需求，这会推高通货膨胀。在英国，新移民似乎推高了伦敦的租金，伦敦的住房供应已经受到限制。类似的效果在澳大利亚也很明显。高盛银行公布的估计表明，澳大利亚目前 50 万人的年化净移民率正在将租金提高 5% 左右。更高的租金导致更高的整体消费者价格指数。移民的需求也可以解释为什么尽管抵押贷款利率较高，但许多富裕国家的房价并没有下降太多。

在接下来的一年左右，移民可能会有所减少。大流行后的“追赶”将结束；富裕世界的劳动力市场正在慢慢放松。然而，有理由相信，新移民的历史高位将在一段时间内保持上升。更受欢迎的政府政策是一个因素。更重要的是，今天的移民会引发明天的移民，因为新移民会带来孩子和伴侣。不久之后，富裕世界在 2010 年代后期的反移民转向将看起来像一种反常现象。 ■

; Sun, 28 May 2023 15:49:52 GMT /内容/0vbl7lt5n3cvp7183eofk9soi8k65vtm https://www.economist.com/finance-and-economics/2023/05/28/a-new-wave-of-mass-migration-has-begun The comic opera of England

你拖着你的柳条篮子穿过细高跟鞋刺破的草坪，在哈哈旁边占了一个位置。你经常说“哈哈”，因为这是你唯一的机会。抚平你的连衣裙或燕尾服，你走进去观看歌剧——在这种情况下，“L'elisir d'amore”，多尼采蒂 1832 年的喜剧乐趣——在长时间的休息时间重新出现，去野餐并垂涎邻居的烛台。在第二幕的锣声响起之前，您漫步在长满睡莲的湖边，伴随着软木塞爆裂声和远处羊羔的咩咩声。

5 月 19 日在格林德伯恩 (Glyndebourne) 开幕的夏季歌剧节在东萨塞克斯 (East Sussex) 幸福乡村的一座都铎式庄园内举行，通常被外国人描述为英国特色的缩影。实际上，它更像是一幅漫画：打扮、喝酒和看老房子是英国人普遍的消遣，但黑领带歌剧和 Pol Roger 是少数人的追求。然而，在 2023 年，格林德伯恩确实提供了一幅国情图景，只是不像你想象的那样。

开幕周末的天气很好，所以顾客不需要像偶尔那样召唤冷静的人在雨中野餐。但是铁路罢工，一个时代的祸害，使这次旅行变得复杂。它取消了返回维多利亚车站的火车，这意味着伦敦人不得不申请退票并开车。 （停车场里安装了一组充电点，但它缺少另一个有用的便利设施：有人，也许是老伊顿公学的工作人员，可以帮你系领结。）

与此同时，歌剧院的舞台是文化战争的战场，也是情节剧的取景地。歌剧的情节充满了有毒的男子气概、受虐待的女主角和种族刻板印象。置之不理或修改，他们很容易让别人不高兴。承认过去一些作品中的“社会假设”“可能会冒犯今天的观众”，格林德伯恩发誓要做得更好。一位常客坐在他的座位上，因为他已经知道这个故事，所以没有打印出概要——也就是说，他呻吟着，除非他们改变了它。多尼采蒂轻而易举地离开了，但节日的“唐乔瓦尼”被指责扼杀了名义上的浪子。

然后是老式的政治，以及最近的资金短缺。制作高端歌剧的成本高得惊人——各地的公司都感到手头拮据。观众正在老龄化。在美国，慈善事业是不稳定的。在英国，国家资助已被削减，导致格林德伯恩取消了通常的秋季巡演（它将改为在其主场举办一些负担得起的演出）。盛大的夏季音乐节没有任何补贴，但门票价格昂贵，而且大部分都是付费会员。如果最好的艺术形式成为富人的专利，那将是可悲的。

在英国田园诗中享受这种欧洲艺术，自然而然地也会反思潜在的联系。格林德伯恩 (Glyndebourne) 的故事将英国人的怪癖与欧洲大陆的才华结合在一起：1934 年，时任庄园主人的约翰·克里斯蒂 (John Christie) 与妻子共同创立了这座庄园，他从德国和奥地利招募了大批难民来为其增添魅力。他的孙子兼现任老板格斯克里斯蒂公开担心英国退欧对经济和歌剧院财务的影响。

巧合的是，“爱情长生不老药”的情节讲述了一个小贩，他兜售一种治疗所有已知疾病的假药，就像一个愤世嫉俗的政客，打算在他被轰动之前离开舞台。在他的情况下，灵丹妙药是一种药水，他的印记很快就会大口大口地吞噬自己。其中之一是 Nemorino，由 Matteo Desole 在这里演唱，他是一个爱上地主的农民（他被一位富有的叔叔救了出来）。

Desole 先生确定了该作品最著名的编号“Una furtiva lagrima”。纳杜斯·威廉姆斯 (Nardus Williams) 像他时髦的爱人阿迪娜 (Adina) 一样闪闪发光。马克西姆·努里萨特 (Maxime Nourissat) 做了一个滑稽的沉默转身，成为庸医的助手。尤其是在醉酒的女性场景中，编舞很滑稽。像往常一样，表演很强。

不过，正如他经常做的那样，以赛亚伯林爵士对格林德伯恩的看法是正确的。 “That something so enchanting could happen in England at all,” the Russian-British thinker wrote in 1984, was “a source of lasting astonishment and delight.” He loved it, in other words, not because it was typical, but because it was exceptional. The true quintessence of England in summer does not recline in Glyndebourne's gardens (“Please do not picnic on the croquet lawn”); rather it basks on pebbly beaches and pub pavements where the English get sozzled and sunburnt on balmy afternoons. ■

; Sun, 28 May 2023 15:35:22 GMT /content/qutk19qa14a000ibdit599ukparang0f https://www.economist.com/culture/2023/05/28/the-comic-opera-of-england America’s debt-ceiling deal means it should now avoid Armageddon

E VEN IN A sharply divided Washington, DC , politics-as-usual sometimes works. America has a history of debt-ceiling drama, staring into the abyss of a government default before reaching a deal at the last minute. This time, too, the familiar pattern has repeated itself. Intense negotiations went down to the wire. But President Joe Biden and Kevin McCarthy, the Republican speaker of the House of Representatives, resolved the final points of an agreement in a phone call on the evening of May 27th.

Some feared that this time would be different. Such is the depth of the partisan divide in Washington nowadays, and so ardent the radicalism of the extremists in both camps, the worry was that a compromise might prove elusive. Republicans were demanding budget cuts on a scale—equivalent to about 25% in real terms—that was unacceptable to Democrats.

Yet the looming deadline concentrated minds as usual. The “X-date”, when the country might be unable to pay its bills unless Congress raised or suspended the debt ceiling of $31.4trn, was fast approaching. Although Janet Yellen, the treasury secretary, had on May 26th moved back her estimate of the X-date from June 1st to June 5th, time was running short to reach a deal and get it through both chambers of Congress. The consequences of a debt default, the first in America's modern history, would be dire: the shock from disruption in the biggest sovereign-debt market, accounting for about one-third of the global total and underpinning pricing in financial markets everywhere, threatened to reverberate through every economy around the world. The gravity of the situation led Mr Biden to cut short his trip to Asia after the G7 summit, and prompted desperate speculation about whether there might be hitherto untested ways around a crisis , for example by invoking the 14th Amendment, in effect declaring the debt ceiling unconstitutional.

So the breakthrough achieved on May 27th came as a relief. The deal, if it gets through Congress, will suspend the debt ceiling for two years. That conveniently puts off any future debt-limit drama to beyond the presidential elections of 2024. There will be limits on some government programmes over those two years, meaning non-defence spending will be flat in the 2024 fiscal year instead of growing, though the cuts will be far less swingeing than Republicans originally wanted.

Details of the deal were due to be released on May 28th. It reportedly includes new work requirements and time limits for some people on food stamps and some other safety-net programmes (though there will be exceptions for homeless people and veterans, and Mr Biden resisted any new work requirements for Medicaid, the health-insurance programme for the poor). Among the more contentious spending cuts, the Internal Revenue Service will get $10bn less than previously planned to enforce tax-collection. The agreement includes some modest provisions aimed at helping speed up environmental reviews of energy projects, a sensitive issue for progressive Democrats, though Republicans are not alone in complaining that such projects too often get bogged down by problems of permits. But military spending, and spending on veterans' care, will still grow. And the White House has resisted any unwinding of Mr Biden's landmark laws, such as the clean-energy investments under the Inflation Reduction Act.

An effort to sell the deal has begun on both sides. Mr McCarthy said it would bring “historic reductions in spending” and “rein in government overreach”. For his part, Mr Biden said: “The agreement represents a compromise, which means not everyone gets what they want.”

A measure of that compromise is that it has already produced noisy disgruntlement among radicals on both sides. For the Republicans, the House Freedom Caucus is said to be exploring ways to make the bill more radical. On the Democratic side, progressives are complaining that it goes too far.

Such discontent means that the deal's journey through Congress will be bumpy. The clock is still ticking. The House is in recess but will return to consider the deal on Wednesday.

Albeit grumpily, and despite opponents on both sides, the deal seems likely to win approval, with support from Democrats and Republicans who are unwilling to push America (and world markets) over the brink. Any celebration at such an outcome should be tempered by the fact that the two-year horizon of the debt-ceiling suspension almost guarantees that you can pencil in renewed fears of debt Armageddon in 2025. But for now, at least, the centre in America has held. ■

; Sun, 28 May 2023 14:45:16 GMT /content/296d4l0lr3drplaijqeqoif5s8nd18lh https://www.economist.com/united-states/2023/05/28/americas-debt-ceiling-deal-means-it-should-now-avoid-armageddon House Republicans are no closer to tying Hunter Biden’s activities to Joe

A t the start of his memoir, “Beautiful Things”, published in 2021, Hunter Biden, the second son of the president of the United States, begins with a single claim that summarises the argument of the book. “I am not Eric Trump or Donald Trump, Jr,” he writes. “I've worked for someone other than my father, rose and fell on my own.”

Over the next 220 pages, he takes readers through his childhood, his deep love of his brother Beau, who died in 2015 at the age of 46, his businesses and, in sordid detail, his use of crack cocaine and alcohol. Yet the theme that keeps coming back is his independence. “There is no question that my last name has opened doors,” the younger Mr Biden admits. And his accomplishments “sometimes crossed into my father's spheres of influence during his two terms as vice-president”. But they were, he maintains, still very much his own, just as his failures and addiction were too, and nothing to do with his father.

Republicans desperately wish they could show otherwise . Since January, the House Committee on Oversight and Accountability, and its Republican chairman, James Comer, have been digging through the younger Biden's records, in a search for something that would tie President Biden to his son's chaotic business practices. On May 10th Mr Comer held a press conference to unveil more details about $10m or so that was paid between 2015 and 2017 to firms owned by Hunter, as well as his uncle, James, both of their wives, Beau's widow and their children, by various foreign sources.

What the committee has not succeeded in showing, however, is anything illegal, or any wrongdoing by the president. Yet Mr Biden may still be hurt by the slow drip of revelations , not least because Hunter's problems are far from over.

The committee's reports so far have highlighted the colossal extent to which the Biden name did indeed open doors. Payments of several million dollars came directly and indirectly from one Chinese tycoon, Ye Jianming. It is far from clear what services Hunter or his uncle provided in exchange for the cash. Mr Ye seemed to harbour unrealistic hopes of influencing the then vice-president by hiring his relatives, and was strung along. In 2018 he was detained for questioning by the Chinese authorities about unrelated corruption, and has since disappeared.

Another lucrative job taken by Hunter, with Burisma, a Ukrainian gas firm, seems similarly to have come with relatively few work requirements. He himself admits he took it because it was not much work. “Its robust compensation initially gave me more time and resources to look after my brother,” he writes in his book.

But despite their access to Mr Comer's subpoena powers, his team have uncovered nothing so far that shows the president benefiting. The extensive private correspondence taken from Hunter Biden's leaked laptop hard drive, which included dozens of voicemails left on his phone by his father, shows nothing either.

Rather, it is a parallel Justice Department investigation into the younger Mr Biden's conduct that is the more imminent headache for the president. The investigation became public in 2020. In late April Hunter Biden's lawyers reportedly met officials at the Justice Department to discuss four potential criminal charges (two misdemeanours and two felonies) that could be brought against him. On May 23rd a whistleblower from the Internal Revenue Service told CBS News that the Justice Department had “slow-walked” its probe of Hunter's finances.

The potential charges include three related to his taxes, and a fourth related to the purchase of a gun in 2018—Mr Biden is suspected of having lied about his extensive illegal-drug use on a background-check form. He has denied any wrongdoing. Morally the potential charges hardly compare to the many awful things Mr Biden freely admits to having done himself in his memoir (which include driving on crack cocaine, hanging out with pimps and trying to fight bouncers). None relates to his alleged “influence peddling”.

But if Hunter is charged, it will be uncomfortable for President Biden, who has been fiercely loyal throughout the saga of his son's addiction. “My son has done nothing wrong,” he said (inappropriately, given the Justice Department's ongoing investigation) in an interview with MSNBC , a cable-news channel, in early May.

An irony is that Republicans are pursuing this even as Donald Trump's own relatives are also involved in legal influence-peddling that is orders of magnitude larger—at least in terms of the money involved. Last year the New York Times reported that Jared Kushner, Mr Trump's son-in-law, received a $2bn investment in his hedge fund from a fund led by the crown prince of Saudi Arabia, on what analysts say are very cushy terms. And Mr Trump himself faces his own criminal indictment, related to hush-money payments he made to Stormy Daniels, a porn star, before the 2016 election.

Yet for Mr Trump, that only makes Hunter's problems all the more useful. “Hunter Biden is a criminal, and nothing happened to him,” the former president said at a conservative conference in March. “Joe Biden is a criminal and nothing ever seems to happen to him,” he added, without any evidence. The reek of hypocrisy spoils the point. But whether it is Hunter or one of Mr Trump's children, there seem to be few consequences for using your powerful father's name to make money. ■

T he moment when his chemistry master pulled a pistol, declared it loaded and waved it in the air was “probably”, says Justin Webb, a broadcaster, the worst moment of his boarding-school career. Winston Churchill would remember the floggings, done until pupils “bled freely” and screamed loudly. George Orwell was beaten so violently that his headmaster broke his riding crop on him and “reduced me to tears”.

That British boarding schools are odd places is not news. For several centuries and for fat fees they provided the English upper classes with a ripping blend of architectural beauty and physical discomfort; with neoclassical corridors and cold showers; with lashings of Latin and just plain lashings. The pupils they produced were an equally idiosyncratic mix of the sophisticated and the childlike, mingling precocious brilliance with speech that never quite left the classroom. It was a heady brew and Britain was intoxicated by it: of the 57 British prime ministers, 20 went to Eton . As Boris Johnson, one of their number, might say: “Crikey!”

Boarding schools are not yet in trouble. Their pupil numbers are relatively constant—around 70,000, owing partly to lots of boarders from abroad. But their charms may be becoming easier to resist. Elite private schools are a less secure route into the most coveted universities than they were. In 2014, 99 pupils were accepted from Eton to Oxbridge; in the 2021-22 academic year, it managed only 47. In contrast Brampton Manor Academy, a state school in London, had 54.

That raises hard questions about value for money. Annual fees for Eton were a mere £861 (around £10,000 today) a year in Mr Johnson's era. Today, its fees are £15,432 “each half” (which, as Eton's website explains, means thrice yearly; £46,296 a year apparently does not stretch to an understanding of fractions). For this, Etonians enjoy one pool; two chapels; three “theatre spaces”; a composer-in-residence; a filmmaker-in-residence; a pet pianist; and a director of “inclusive education”, who notes that to promote diversity at Eton it is important “to enable people to talk about uncomfortable things”. Like, say, those fees.

Perhaps the most profound threat to boarding schools is more fundamental. And that is the idea that to send a child as young as seven or eight away from home is not privilege but brutality; that even if this education goes well—no abuse or bullying; first eleven for cricket; scones for tea; huzzahs all round—it will still have been very wrong. Older adolescents might well find the whole experience much less cruel, perhaps even a relief. But as John Bowlby, a psychologist who was the father of attachment theory, put it: “I wouldn't send a dog away to boarding school at age seven.” Richard Beard, a writer who lacerates private schools in his book, “Sad Little Men”, echoes the theme. The architectural beauty and bells and whistles of boarding schools, he says, are like the label on a dog-food tin which “isn't for the dog; it's for the person buying it”.

Send your offspring to boarding school, agrees Alex Renton, an author and campaigner who was abused at his prep school, and “you're putting your child into care. You're just paying for it.” Psychologists increasingly argue that posh care leads to bad outcomes. In 2011 the term “boarding-school syndrome” was coined by Joy Schaverien, a psychotherapist, to cover a series of symptoms such as depression, emotional repression and serial broken relationships. A group called “Boarding School Survivors” provides therapeutic help to former boarders. Since its foundation in 1990 it has treated hundreds.

Their defenders argue that boarding schools have changed. To extrapolate from the experiences of children 40 years ago is “obtuse”, says Gavin Horgan, headmaster of Millfield School and chair of the Boarding School Association. “It's a completely different environment.” Whereas once pupils were sent away for months, many young boarders are now weekly; they can video-call home each day. Attitudes are different, too: today boarding-school teachers talk not about stiff upper lips but safeguarding and mental-health first aiders. Moreover, boarding-school syndrome is posited rather than proven by hard data.

But critics say that this is partly because no one has bothered to gather the information. Snobbery and a national obsession with old stone mean that it is still a struggle to see people in Palladian mansions as deprived. Mr Webb thinks he and his fellow-boarders were not privileged. “If anything, the opposite…they should've been at home, having tea with mum and dad.” To send him away was, he says, “a crime”.

The cruelty of this system was deliberate, not accidental. Victorian Britons, believing that the battle of Waterloo had been won on the playing-fields of Eton, set about creating new fields and new Etons (each a “gimcrack copy” of it, wrote EM Forster) in order to mass produce the upper-middle classes. Children, removed from the “softening” influence of mothers, were put in uniform clothes, in uniform beds, in uniform dorms, where they spoke uniform vocabulary (“Topping! Pax! Sneak!”) with an increasingly uniform accent: the clipped tones of Received Pronunciation ( RP ) are thought to have emerged as part of this school-led standardisation of the upper-class self.

The empire might have been happy with the results, its children less so. Churchill, Orwell, CS Lewis—all write viciously, and brilliantly, about their schools. One of the best arguments in favour of boarding schools is the quality of the prose attacking them; one of the best arguments against is its content. As John Le Carré put it: “The British are known to be mad. But in the maiming of their privileged young, they are criminally insane.” ■

; Sun, 28 May 2023 09:50:33 GMT /content/en4h4vdtvm4j6n6brtqbk7o4nge1qt6n https://www.economist.com/britain/2023/05/28/sad-little-boys-the-backlash-against-britains-boarding-schools Japan’s hot-spring resorts are blocking geothermal energy plants

W HITE STEAM rises from the waters of Okuhida Onsengo in snowy northern Japan. Each year thousands of bathers from across the country travel to soak in these hallowed hot springs. Down the road, meanwhile, the spring's underground reservoirs are being put to a new use: last December the Nakao Geothermal Power Plant began using steam from them to generate electricity. With a maximum output of 1,998 kilowatts, the plant could supply electricity to 4,000 households.

With over 100 active volcanoes, Japan is estimated to have a potential geothermal resource of 23 gigawatts. That would represent a stable, round-the-clock, zero-carbon power supply equivalent to the output of 23 nuclear reactors. But the Nakao plant is a rarity—Japan has hardly developed its huge geothermal reserves. Just 2% have been tapped; geothermal energy provides 0.3% of the country's total electricity supply. Japan holds the third-largest geothermal potential in the world after America and Indonesia, but ranks tenth in terms of geothermal power generation, trailing less well-endowed countries such as Kenya. For a country that is heavily dependent on imported energy and already struggling to honour its commitment to decarbonise its economy by 2050, this represents a huge missed opportunity.

Japan's sprawling and influential onsen (hot spring) industry is the main obstacle to geothermal development. Though many geologists reckon there is little chance of geothermal plants negatively affecting bathing pools (which are generally filled by much shallower aquifers than the geothermal reservoirs energy companies look for), the onsen industry is unconvinced. “The government relies on hot springs for its tourism—what are they going to do if the hot springs disappear because they keep building geothermal power plants?” says Sato Yoshiyasu, vice president of the Japan Onsen Association, a big industry group, which opposes “unruly development” of geothermal. Japan's 3,000 hot-spring resorts routinely withhold the consent necessary for development to proceed. And the fact that they are deeply rooted in Japanese culture, and attract around 130m visitors a year, has largely deterred the government from pushing back.

There are other obstacles to geothermal development. Some 80% of Japan's reserves are located in national parks. Much of Japan is mountainous, which increases construction costs. Its underground geology is also relatively complex, with layers of hard rock that are difficult to drill through. Whereas countries, such as Indonesia, that produce a lot of geothermal power often have relatively large, well-connected power-stations, Japanese plants tend to be small and scattered. Geothermal in Japan is “promising” but requires “diligent effort”, says Ehara Sachio of the Institute for Geothermal Information, a think-tank in Saitama, near Tokyo.

With enough political will, none of these barriers is insurmountable, however, as Japan demonstrated in its response to the oil crisis of the 1970s. Back then it launched an initiative, known as the “Sunshine Project”, to promote alternative energy sources, including solar, hydrogen and geothermal. The New Energy and Industrial Technology Development Organisation (NEDO), a government institution established in 1980 as part of this effort, conducted a nationwide assessment of geothermal potential. Despite the same fierce opposition from the onsen industry, it led to the construction of dozens of geothermal power stations across the country. By 1996, over 500MW of generating capacity had been added.

As oil prices stabilised and more nuclear power stations came online, Japan's spurt of enthusiasm for geothermal petered out. But the meltdown at the Fukushima nuclear plant in 2011, which turned public opinion against nuclear power, has brought another spurt. Japan now hopes to triple geothermal output by 2030. Businesses and local governments are considering over 50 possible sites to build new geothermal power plants.

To that end, the government is also eyeing next-generation geothermal technology. Japan and America recently signed an agreement to collaborate on geothermal projects, including on research for supercritical geothermal—which involves drilling deep wells to access ultra-hot fluids. NEDO is working on a pilot project for supercritical geothermal and aims to commence large-scale power generation by 2050. Mr Ehara reckons such advanced technologies could ensure geothermal provides more than 10% of Japan's energy mix. (America's Department of Energy is aiming to get 8.5% of American electricity generation from geothermal by 2050.)

In the short-run, conventional geothermal plants remain a better way to reduce Japan's carbon emissions. Developing them is becoming slightly easier. The timeline for environmental assessments was recently shortened from over a decade to eight years. The rules on developing national-park land were eased around a decade ago. Perhaps more promisingly, some geothermal energy producers, such as Cenergy, which runs the plant at Nakao, are developing their own innovative ways to mollify the objectors.

Hot water extracted at the plant is not, as is usual, returned directly underground. It is piped to local onsens. The two parties enjoy a “win-win” situation, says Uchino Masamitsu, a local onsen owner. This co-operation appears to be sparking interest in using the hot waters in other ways, too. Some local householders are using their heat to grow tropical fruits such as bananas and dragon fruit. “Geothermal,” sighs Mr Uchino approvingly, “opens up so many dreams.” ■
